DOCNAME: CASE OF SCHÖNENBERGER AND DURMAZ v. SWITZERLAND
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 8;No separate issue under Art. 10;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The first applicant , PERSON , who is a NORP citizen born in DATE , practises as a PERSON ( lawyer ) in GPE .
The second applicant , PERSON , who is a NORP national born in DATE , lives at ORG , in GPE . He is a taxi - driver .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , acting on a statement by CARDINAL O , the district prosecutor ( GPE ) for PERSON ( GPE of GPE ) issued a warrant for Mr. PERSON ’s arrest , in connection with suspected offences under federal legislation relating to the misuse of drugs .

The applicant was arrested on DATE by the GPE police and taken to GPE DATE , where he was questioned for the first time by officials from the prosecutor ’s office . He was further questioned and also confronted with other suspects on CARDINAL and DATE , and on each occasion he cooperated by answering all the questions put to him .

CARDINAL . ORG Mr. PERSON ’s wife , who had been informed of the arrest on DATE , spoke on the telephone to the ORG district prosecutor on CARDINAL and DATE . On these occasions she asked him whether her husband had a lawyer . He replied that he had not but added that he would take care of it . She also wrote to her husband on DATE and DATE . In the second letter , which reached him on DATE , she expressed the hope that the " lawyer " - whose name she did not mention - " would look after [ him ] " . On DATE , she asked Mr. PERSON to take charge of Mr. PERSON ’s defence .

The first applicant immediately called the district prosecutor to advise him and to say that he would be sending authorisation forms and a letter . Also , on DATE , he sent a letter and enclosure to the district prosecutor ’s office , as required by the relevant legislation , requesting the district prosecutor to forward them to the addressee .

The enclosure comprised a copy of the covering letter to the district prosecutor , CARDINAL forms giving authority to act and a letter to Mr. PERSON , which read as follows ( translation from the NORP ) :
" Sir ,

I am instructed by your wife to undertake your defence . You will find enclosed CARDINAL forms giving me authority to act for you . If you wish to authorise me to represent you , please send CARDINAL of the forms to the district prosecutor and return the other one to me ( duly signed ) .

It is my duty to point out to you that you are entitled to refuse to make any statement . Anything you say may be used in evidence against you . If you choose to remain silent , the district prosecutor will have to prove your guilt by other means ( witnesses , etc . ) . He will usually then try to influence you by arguing that in that case you will remain in custody on remand until such time as he has questioned witnesses , other suspects , etc . If this does not worry you ( i.e. a possible prolongation of your detention on remand ) , it will be to your advantage to exercise your right not to make any statement .
Once I have received your authority to act , I shall apply for permission to visit you and will come and see you . At all events , be patient : you will have to be released at some stage !
Yours faithfully ... "

CARDINAL . ORG The district prosecutor probably received the letter and enclosure for Mr. PERSON on DATE , but kept them from him without telling him that he had received them . On DATE , he asked Mr. PERSON to choose a lawyer . Mr. PERSON , being unable to pay for one , applied for the only GPE lawyer he knew , Mr. PERSON , to be assigned officially to him ; the presiding judge of ORG duly appointed Mr. PERSON on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG In an order made on DATE , the prosecutor ’s office decided not to communicate to Mr. PERSON the letter and forms which were intended for him . It did so on the following ground ( translation from the NORP ) :

" As long as PERSON is not the suspect ’s authorised legal representative , the general provisions of the Prisons Ordinance [ see paragraph CARDINAL below ] apply to him . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) prohibits the forwarding of letters concerning the preparation of a case for trial . In the present letter , PERSON has recommended to the suspect a particular course of conduct for the preparation of the case . In virtue of the aforementioned provision , his letter will therefore not be forwarded . "
The prosecutor ’s office returned to Mr. PERSON the said documents together with the copy of the covering letter .

CARDINAL . ORG On various dates DATE , Mr. PERSON was again questioned and confronted with other suspects . He also received visits from Mr. PERSON . On DATE , Mr. PERSON had asked the presiding judge of ORG to offer Mr. PERSON the possibility of choosing between Mr. PERSON and himself as his defence lawyer . The CARDINAL lawyers had a conversation on DATE , as a result of which they agreed that Mr. PERSON would continue to assist Mr. PERSON and that Mr. PERSON would challenge the order made on DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL to CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Mr. PERSON was freed on DATE . On CARDINAL DATE the GPE district prosecutor ordered that he had no case to answer as it could not be excluded beyond all possible doubt that someone else had been mistaken for him . In respect of his detention on remand , the prosecutor awarded him MONEY ( CHF ) which the ORG increased to MONEY on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicants lodged CARDINAL appeals against the order of CARDINAL March CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) ; the first of these was rejected by ORG of the GPE of GPE on DATE , and the second was dismissed by the presiding judge of ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , they lodged a public - law appeal with ORG against the decision of ORG ; they alleged an infringement of the federal LAW and of the LAW . During the proceedings they stated that they did not propose to challenge the dismissal of their second appeal .
CARDINAL . ORG In a judgment on DATE , which was notified on DATE , ORG allowed the appeal in part .

It noted in the first place that Mr. PERSON could not rely on the privileges conferred on prisoners’ defence lawyers under LAW . ORG added that the prosecutor ’s office had not infringed either the LAW or the LAW by intercepting Mr. PERSON ’s letter to Mr. PERSON , since it related to pending criminal proceedings and gave the addressee advice on the behaviour to adopt during the investigation .

On the other hand , ORG held that the decision to withhold the CARDINAL authorisation forms and the copy of the covering letter to the prosecutor ’s office was contrary to the LAW : since these documents did not relate to pending criminal proceedings , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) could not be relied on in respect of them . ORG also pointed out that a person who has been charged with a criminal offence is at all times entitled to ask for a lawyer and to receive a form for giving authority to act . It concluded that the disputed measure was a disproportionate restriction on freedom of correspondence and on the rights of the defence . It consequently set aside ORG decision and awarded the applicants costs of QUANTITY .

CARDINAL . ORG According to the general principles of criminal procedure , a suspect is under no obligation to make any statements . ORG has held that , LAW , he has the right to remain silent and that he can not normally be held to have culpably obstructed the proceedings on the sole ground that he has refused to reply to questions , unless there has been some abuse of the right ( Judgments of ORG , vol . CARDINAL ( DATE ) , part I a ) , p. CARDINAL , and vol . CARDINAL ( DATE ) , part I a ) , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG In the GPE of GPE , the monitoring of correspondence with persons in custody is governed by LAW DATE ( ORG Zürich vom CARDINAL . DATE über die Bezirksgefängnisse ) , which was made under LAW of the law of DATE by which LAW was enacted .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) reads as follows ( translation from NORP ) :

" No correspondence with co - prisoners and former co - prisoners ( except for close relatives ) shall be allowed . Letters jeopardising the purpose of detention or prison security shall not be forwarded ; letters relating to pending criminal proceedings shall be forwarded only if they form part of correspondence with a defence lawyer . A prisoner shall be informed if a letter is not forwarded . "

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE , ORG considered the constitutionality of various provisions of GPE of DATE . As regards the restrictions on freedom of correspondence , it noted the following ( translation from NORP ) :

" Section CARDINAL lays down in particular that letters ‘ whose content is improper’ or which relate to pending criminal proceedings shall not be forwarded . Correspondence with co - prisoners or former co - prisoners is likewise prohibited . On the other hand , communications addressed to supervising authorities or to a defence lawyer are not subject to any restrictions .

The applicant alleges that prohibiting communications ‘ whose content is improper’ goes much too far and leaves too great a discretion to the officials responsible for monitoring correspondence . In his submission , the prohibition should apply only to communications whose content is ‘ illicit’ . This change of wording would make no appreciable difference , since the second concept is likewise very imprecise in the present context . The applicant does not dispute the need to prohibit the dispatch of letters with a particular type of content , and that is the very purpose of the monitoring . It is clear , therefore , that any correspondence which might assist in the preparation of escape plans or the commission of fresh criminal offences , or which could have an impermissible influence on criminal proceedings ( danger of collusion ) must be prohibited . Even assuming that it is in principle desirable to maintain contacts with the outside world , these contacts must not compromise the purpose of detention . Moreover , the supervising authorities must also be given the right to hold back any communications which might jeopardise order in the prison . Conversely , the authorities can not refuse to forward communications which do not jeopardise either the purpose of detention or order in the prison and which are permissible in their quantity ( s. CARDINAL ) . It is accordingly of little consequence whether or not the supervising authority approves the content of such communications ( cf . , on the legal situation in GPE , ORG decision of DATE , vol . CARDINAL , no . CARDINAL ) . It is not possible to make an accurate general statement of where the line should be drawn , since it depends on the particular circumstances of each case . The general principle laid down in the disputed ordinance accordingly can not be criticised as being unconstitutional , at least not if regard is had to the fact that correspondence with the supervising authorities and defence lawyers is not subject to any marked degree of control . " ( Judgments of ORG , vol . CARDINAL , part I a ) , pp . CARDINAL )
